item.title: Steam’s Latest Horror Hit isn’t for Everyone, But It’s Perfect for Me
item.description:
Steam is a treasure trove of horror games, and, amid countless horror experiences that are derivative or unapologetic clones of whatever inspired them, there are tons of glimmering gems waiting to be discovered. I’m a huge horror fan, but it’s rare nowadays that I’ll be enamored by the hook of a brand-new horror game or IP. I’m quite picky when it comes to horror, simply due to how bottomless the sea of mediocre or bad horror games is, yet there is one popular horror game on Steam that immediately struck me as novel in both its gameplay loop and eerie art style: Trioskaz and Critical Reflex’s No, I’m Not a Human .

You may already be familiar with at least one version of this game if you have played No, I’m Not a Human ’s Steam demo, which was released on June 8, 2025, much less when it was packaged into the anthological Violent Horror Stories that was released on August 7, 2024. As a horror visual novel game, No, I’m Not a Human doesn’t rely on ubiquitous tropes that horror games are typically saturated with. That said, it’s precisely the lack of jump-scares and other tired genre mechanics that swept me off my feet and had me instantly falling for No, I’m Not a Human .

No, I’m Not a Human Preys on My Biggest Fear: Social Anxiety

The TL;DR of No, I’m Not a Human boils down to anxiously judging strangers based on their physical appearance while attempting not to let their odd or downright egregious personality traits or dialogue deceive you into thinking they’re something they’re not. Therefore, the game is particularly curated toward anyone who has anxiety in social interactions.

I’d be able to empathize wholly with this Steam game protagonist if it wasn’t for their supposed willingness to allow their home to be a haven for villainous aliens. Ironically, No, I’m Not a Human brilliantly parries what would otherwise be my inherent defense mechanism of never opening the door to any stranger, let alone answering it, by ensuring that I’ll be killed if I’m alone in the house.

No, I’m Not a Human ’s replayability is terrific, with oodles of endings based on your choices and a wealth of potential with the randomization of certain characters either being a human or a “Visitor” in each playthrough.

No, I’m Not a Human’s Steam Popularity is Evidence That Horror is More Than Jump-Scares

Like The Mortuary Assistant , another Steam horror game I adore, No, I’m Not a Human revolves around a unique, formulaic gameplay loop. Unlike The Mortuary Assistant , though, No, I’m Not a Human isn’t peppered with jump scares. No, I’m Not a Human is arguably rather tranquil, actually, especially when you know you’re safe in the daytime and can drink beers or carry a cat in the hallway, until nighttime’s ominous green hue is cast upon the protagonist’s house, and you’re forced to interact with people who’ve arrived at the door.

No, I’m Not a Human’s Steam Ratings

  • 85.71% ‘Very Positive’ across 10,256 user reviews.
  • Currently popular.
  • 2,494 players at the time of this writing, a 24-hour peak of 4,437 players, and an 8,248 all-time peak 27 days ago (September 15, 2025, the date No, I’m Not a Human was released).

So, while No, I’m Not a Human may not frighten everyone, and will surely not be what everybody is hoping for out of a horror game, it’s the precise brand of horror that I’ve been craving. I love horror across its wide breadth of subgenres—survival horror ( Resident Evil ), psychological horror ( Silent Hill ), walking simulator horror ( P.T. ), stealth horror ( Alien: Isolation ), and so forth—but No, I’m Not a Human ’s horror subgenre, whether that’s visual novel, point-and-click, narrative, or some distinct brand, is what I hope to see more of in the future. Here’s hoping that Steam can produce more horror games like No, I’m Not a Human , with dreadfully rich atmosphere and gripping storytelling momentum.

It’s precisely the lack of jump-scares and other tired genre mechanics that swept me off my feet and had me instantly falling for No, I’m Not a Human .

No, I'm not a Human

item.title: Pokemon GO Reveals New Leveling Rewards
item.description:
Pokemon GO has revealed new leveling rewards coming to the game on October 15. Additionally, the leveling system for Pokemon GO is getting some changes, including increasing the Trainer level cap to 80. The aim of these alterations is to make progressing through the game faster and more rewarding.

One of the goals for many Pokemon GO players is to achieve the maximum level. While reaching the Trainer cap is no small feat, there are numerous ways for players to gain XP, including catching Pokemon and hatching eggs. Furthermore, the game often hosts events that include new opportunities to level up. With the game being over nine years old, some players have managed to reach level 50. However, the developer is looking to keep the grind going for the community.

Pokemon GO Increases Trainer Level Cap

Starting on October 15, Pokemon GO will increase the Trainer level cap from 50 to 80, giving players more levels to earn in the game. This is part of a larger revamping of the level system, allowing players to progress more easily and earn rewards more often. Some of the new leveling rewards offer increased storage capacity in Pokemon GO . New avatar rewards will also be added at various levels. These new avatar rewards begin to unlock at level 25 and feature pieces of clothing that players can use to customize their in-game Trainer.

New Avatar Rewards

  • Level 25: Poke Ball Cap
  • Level 30: Poke Ball Shoes
  • Level 35: Poke Ball Jacket
  • Level 40: Great Ball Cap
  • Level 45: Great Ball Shoes
  • Level 50: Great Ball Jacket
  • Level 55: Ultra Ball Cap
  • Level 60: Ultra Ball Shoes
  • Level 65: Ultra Ball Jacket
  • Level 71: Level 71 Shoes
  • Level 73: Level 73 Shades
  • Level 75: Level 75 Pants
  • Level 77: Level 77 Pose
  • Level 79: Level 79 Hairstyle (Short) and Level 79 Hairstyle (Long)
  • Level 80: Level 80 Jacket

Besides new level rewards, the free Daily Adventure Egg is being added, giving players another way to gain XP in Pokemon GO . As the name suggests, players will automatically get a Daily Adventure Egg after logging in at the start of a new day. The egg hatches after a distance of 1km and grants 10,000 XP. It is worth noting that players must be level 15 or higher and only one Daily Adventure Egg can be incubated at a time. Pokemon GO is also making it easier for players at level 70 or above to become Lucky Friends if they are already Best Friends.

Since Pokemon GO is adjusting the leveling curve, the amount of XP needed for various milestones is changing. According to the developer, 203,353,000 XP will be required to reach the new level 80 Trainer cap. Furthermore, players will no longer have to do the Level-Up Research tasks for levels 41 to 50 starting on October 15. Instead, there will now be Level-Up Research tasks for levels 71 through 80. It will be interesting to see how these changes impact players' accounts, as the developer noted that “all the XP you’ve earned so far will be applied to the rebalanced leveling curve to determine your new Trainer level.” Fortunately, no one will see their level decrease, with all players level 23 or higher guaranteed an increase.

XP requirements for key milestone levels

  • Level 10: 48,000 total XP
  • Level 20: 258,000 total XP
  • Level 30: 1,083,000 total XP
  • Level 40: 3,953,000 total XP
  • Level 50: 12,753,000 total XP
  • Level 60: 34,353,000 total XP
  • Level 70: 85,853,000 total XP
  • Level 80: 203,353,000 total XP

As players prepare for these new changes to the level system to take effect, October is already shaping up to be an exciting time for the game. Specifically, the Harvest Festival is ongoing until October 16, and the first part of the Halloween 2025 event for Pokemon GO begins on October 21, bringing Poltchageist and Sinistcha to the game. Additionally, the Pokemon Legends: Z-A Celebration Event starts on October 16, corresponding to the release of the new game for Switch and Switch 2. Hopefully, these and other events will provide players with more opportunities to earn the XP they need to level up their Trainers.

102
8.4 /10

Pokémon GO

Pokémon GO is an immersive open-world multiplayer RPG that enables you to live your own RPG adventure in augmented reality. Find and evolve all Pokémon and battle with other players in AR online in this multiplayer adventure RPG.

COMPLETE YOUR POKÉDEX AND INCREASE YOUR TRAINER LEVEL!
Catch your favourite Pokémon as you explore the open world in augmented reality, trade them with other Trainers, or get the chance to catch a Pokémon after winning a Raid. You can also collect Pokémon by hatching eggs through walking! Evolve your Pokémon in your Pokédex, gain levels to catch more powerful Pokémon and earn adventure rewards during a Raid in multiplayer or online PvP battle.

EXPERIENCE THE ADVENTURE IN MULTIPLAYER AND PvP!
Start your own adventure and challenge other Trainers online in PvP during epic Gym battles or in the GO Battle League. You can also enjoy multiplayer by facing off with other players in PvP battles to win rewards, or team up with other Trainers for a chance to catch Pokémon after a Raid Battle.

CREATE YOUR OWN ADVENTURE!
Customise your avatar, join one of the three teams and pick your Buddy Pokémon from your Pokédex to journey by your side in this AR adventure RPG.

SWITCH BETWEEN THE REAL WORLD AND THE VIRTUAL WORLD WITH THE AR+ MODE!
Bring the RPG to the real world and search for Pokémon in locations around you. With the AR+ mode, Pokémon appear right in front of you — Catch it with your PokéBall and add it to your Pokédex.

Catch your favourite Pokémon in AR as you explore the world and battle online with other Trainers in PvP and Raid battles.

Cross-Platform Play
Yes

item.title: Megabonk: Fragile Challenge Guide
item.description:
Whenever players complete a map tier in Megabonk , they gain access to various challenges in that same tier. Players can attempt these challenges in order to complete quests and unlock characters and other perks. However, they are also fun for players who want to add some challenge to the game and break the routine of simply playing the game and eliminating the Stage Boss.

One of the many challenges that players will receive once they complete the first tier of the Forest map is the Fragile Challenge, which can only be completed if players take down the Stage Boss without taking damage or ever touching an enemy. This guide will provide players with tips to help them get through this complicated challenge in Megabonk .

How to Complete the Fragile Challenge in Megabonk

Before starting the Fragile Challenge, players should know the exact rules, so they know what will cause them to fail the challenge. Players will fail the Fragile Challenge in Megabonk if they:

  • Lose HP
  • Lose shield
  • Touch an enemy
  • Lose health due to fall damage
  • Evade a hit
  • Reflect a hit
  • Use Megachad's flex ability

Since the challenge is set on the Forest map, most of the danger lies in hitting enemies, as most will only deal close-up, melee damage. However, these enemies can be overwhelming and hard to dodge, especially the slim monsters that come running at the player or swarm attacks.

Additionally, players have to be careful and watch out for the mini-bosses and the Stage Boss, as all of these have ranged attacks. There will also be exploding enemies at some point, but these can be easier to dodge, as they will only burst and deal damage if players get too close to them.

Below, players will find several tips that will help them get through the Fragile Challenge in Megabonk . There is a Fragile Challenge for each tier of the Forest map, but since there are no new enemy types, gamers have to reapply each tip until they make it to the next tier.

Purchase Toggle

The Toggle ability is almost mandatory for completing challenges in Megabonk . With Toggle, players can disable items and tomes that they've previously unlocked. So, they will still have the starting items and tomes as options in the upgrade offers, but they can still disable a wide variety of items, making them more likely to come across better options for their run .

This way, if players want to try out a specific strategy or disable offers that simply won't be helpful and are not worth being in the tome and item pool, they can disable weapons, tomes, and items at will.

Disable HP/Shield Tomes and Items

Once players have purchased Toggle in the Shop, they will be able to disable purchased upgrades. Since players can't lose any health at all, it won't be worth investing in shield, HP, or any regenerative healing item. Therefore, players can disable them to increase their chance of encountering useful items that will greatly improve their odds of succeeding at the challenge.

  • Here are the tomes and items that are worth disabling before attempting the Fragile Challenge in Megabonk :

    Tomes

    • Thorns
    • Bloody
    • Armor

    Items

    • Cactus
    • Demonic Blade
    • Demonic Blood
    • Leeching Crystal
    • Kevin
    • Quin's Mask
    • Toxic Barrel
    • Gamer Goggles
    • Chonkplate
    • Speed Boi

  • Here are items and tomes that cannot be disabled but should be ignored for this run:

    Tomes

    • Regen
    • Shield
    • HP

    Items

    • Borgar
    • Slippery Ring
    • Oats
    • Medkit
    • Golden Shield
    • Electric Plug
    • Coward's Cloak
    • Phantom Shroud
    • Campfire
    • Spiky Shield
    • Mirror
    • Za Warudo

The item above would either grant players lifesteal, more HP, regeneration, evasion, or require them to take damage. Therefore, they are not useful or would only be activated if players met the failing conditions for the challenge.

Pick a Strategy that Suits Your Playstyle

There is a wide range of characters in Megabonk , and each character will fit each player's playstyle. When it comes to the Fragile Challenge, players can either pick a faster character that is able to avoid enemies and ranged attacks or a character that can deal enough damage from the get-go that they won't even have the chance to get close to the player.

For players to succeed, they will want to choose a character that they feel comfortable playing, and that might be a fast yet fragile character, like Calcium and Tony McZoom, or a slower character with particularly useful weapons, such as Megachad or Ogre.

Invest in Some Agility

Even if players prefer to use their upgrade offers on their weapons and tomes, it is worth investing in their character's agility stat, since it makes it easier to dodge enemies, especially once Lil' Bark appears.

The Stage Boss has a strong, ranged attack that spreads across a wide area both vertically and horizontally. This is the hardest attack to dodge, so if the player's character isn't able to move fast enough, they will undoubtedly get hit and fail the challenge. It might not be necessary for characters such as Calcium to invest in agility, but slower characters, such as Megachad, Sir Oofie, and CL4NK will really benefit from it.

Players will want to keep in mind that enemies will spawn just about anywhere, whether it's in front of the player or behind them. This means that if they go too fast, they might just walk into an enemy and fail the challenge.

Ranged Weapons Are the Way to Go

Getting up close and personal can be particularly difficult when attempting the Fragile Challenge in Megabonk . This is exactly why picking ranged weapons for this challenge can facilitate players' lives.

Weapons such as the Wireless Dagger and the Slutty Rocket will attack enemies even if the player keeps their distance, making it a much safer option compared to swords and other weapons that require the user to get close to the target. If players are having trouble dodging attacks or hordes, they might want to avoid riskier weapons , such as the Sword or Aura.

Memorize Boss Attacks

Bosses will follow the player around the map; if they walk too far away from it, the boss will teleport closer to them. Therefore, gamers will have to learn how to deal with them. Each boss on the Forest map has different attacks, and knowing how they'll strike is key to avoiding each hit and making it out alive. Here is what players can expect from each boss's attack on the Forest map:

  • Chunkham the Terrible - Has a ranged attack that creates a bubble of mud that bursts, damaging and slowing down the player
  • Stone Golem - Has a ranged attack that causes stones to rise from the ground, following and damaging the player
  • Lil Bark - Has a ranged attack that causes branches to rise from the ground, either one or several across a larger area
9.3 /10

Megabonk

item.title: Gen 10 Pokemon Images Leak Online
item.description:
Images have leaked from what appears to be the tenth generation of Pokemon games. Though Pokemon fans are eagerly awaiting the launch of Pokemon Legends: Z-A , some players are already looking forward to what the future will hold for the series past that point.

Pokemon Scarlet and Violet was a difficult spot for the Pokemon series, with the games promising a lot but struggling to deliver at launch. Technical problems, visual glitches, and bugs kept players from enjoying the games to their fullest, but a series of patches helped to iron out the worst of it. Since then, the launch of the Switch 2 has allowed Pokemon Scarlet and Violet to perform much better, which has served to excite fans as to what future Pokemon games built for the Switch 2 will be like.

Pokemon Gen 10 Images Leak Online

A slew of Pokemon leaks have recently emerged on the web, and with them, two images allegedly showing the next Pokemon games in development. Previous leaks have indicated that the next Pokemon games, currently thought to be titled Pokemon Wind and Waves , will be set in Southeast Asia and Indonesia-like regions, and fittingly, the images shared by CentroLeaks have a tropical and jungle-like appearance. One image shows a better view of the landscape, with towering trees, low-lying foliage, and Pokemon scattered everywhere, going about their daily lives as the trainer looks on. A second image shows how full of life the region could be, with multiple Pokemon around, with some health bars indicating the presence of more lurking in the area.

The leaked images, in combination with some of the other information that's leaked, like claims that Pokemon Wind and Waves will include procedural generation, have led to a lot of curiosity from the community at large. Other claims include the addition of new Baby Pokemon, with an emphasis on Weather Moves. The opening of the game may be considerably different from predecessor as well, as it's alleged that players will visit a hotel that will kick off their adventure, rather than starting off on a journey from a Professor close to home.

While these rumors are tantalizing, it's important to take them with a grain of salt until they're corroborated or denied by official sources. It's also possible for valid information to change during the development cycle, with some players pointing to how early development images of Pokemon Scarlet and Violet looked quite different from the game players eventually got. For now, though, this is likely to stir a lot more excitement for the future of Pokemon .

item.title: 6 Games That Let You Play As A Powerful Witch
item.description:
F ew things in gaming feel quite as satisfying as stepping into the pointy boots of a witch who can bend reality to her will. Whether it’s summoning unknowable, eldritch horrors from beyond the veil, brewing up some delightfully mischievous potions, or just stylishly dismantling entire waves of angels and demons, these are the games that let players revel in the pure, unadulterated power fantasy of witchcraft.Some of them are moody and gothic, while others are bright and playful. Every one of the following games gives players an arsenal of spells that makes every encounter feel like a glorious, beautiful spectacle.

Black Witchcraft

When Gothic Horror Meets Action RPG

This one is pure gothic romance, plunging players headfirst into a world inspired by the dark, mournful works of Edgar Allan Poe. It's a side-scrolling action RPG that casts players as Ligeia, a powerful witch with a transforming, sentient demon sword, who is tasked with stopping the resurrection of the cursed Roderick Usher. Its wonderfully moody, almost oppressive aesthetic and its gothic setting pair beautifully with the fast-paced, stylish, combo-driven combat.

Spells aren't just bog-standard ranged attacks here; they are beautiful, expressive extensions of Ligeia's dark personality, letting players chain together magic and melee attacks for some truly devastating results. The creepy, haunted environments feel alive, full of cursed paintings and whispering books and unsettling foes that give a real weight to every step. For fans of witches with a bit of theatrical flair, this is pure magic.

Little Witch Academia: Chamber of Time

A Witchy Slice of Life

Little Witch Academia: Chamber of Time
Adventure
Action RPG
Fighting
Systems
Released
November 30, 2017

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
T // Violence, Suggestive Themes, Partial Nudity, Crude Humor
Developer(s)
A Plus
Publisher(s)
Bandai Namco Entertainment
Platform(s)
Windows, PlayStation 4
Powered by

For players who feel like stepping right into the world of the beloved anime and never leaving, this game is the one. Gamers play as Akko and her friends as they explore the wonderful, magical halls of Luna Nova Magical Academy, only to stumble into a mysterious time loop that forces them to uncover secrets and battle monsters in a surprisingly deep, dungeon-crawling RPG format.

The real, pure charm of this lies in its incredibly faithful recreation of the anime’s unique humor and wonderful tone. In between the battles, there’s plenty of time for chatting with classmates, doing silly little side quests, and getting wrapped up in Akko’s well-meaning but usually disastrous antics. It’s a rare, beautiful little game that lets witchcraft feel cozy and mischievous, rather than purely destructive.

Bayonetta 3

When Being Overpowered Feels Like a Legitimate Art Form

Bayonetta 3
9 /10
8.5 /10
Released
October 28, 2022

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
m
Developer(s)
Platinum Games
Platform(s)
Switch
Powered by

There's powerful. And then there's Bayonetta . This game doesn’t just let you play as a witch; it makes gamers feel like the most stylish, untouchable, impossibly powerful force on the entire planet. Bayonetta’s iconic, hair-based magic returns, of course, but now it’s paired with the new "Demon Slave" mechanic. This lets players summon towering, city-block-leveling eldritch creatures in the middle of a fight.

The whole game thrives on pure, unadulterated spectacle. Every single battle is a beautiful, chaotic dance of bullets, kicks, and spells punctuated by gloriously over-the-top set pieces. It's absurd. It’s excessive. It’s glorious. Few games lean this hard into the pure fantasy of being untouchable, and Bayonetta 3 delivers it all with a wink, a smirk, and a flourish.

Elden Ring: Nightreign

Cradling The Night, One Spell At a Time

Elden Ring Nightreign
9 /10
21
8.7 /10
Released
May 30, 2025

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Developer(s)
From Software
Platform(s)
PlayStation 5, PlayStation 4, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S, Xbox One, PC
Powered by

Though t he Nightreign expansion for Elden Ring features a whole host of playable Nightfarers, the Recluse emerges as a sorceress woven from the fabric of night and consequence. A character who wields both Intelligence and Faith, she can draw upon deep, elemental sorceries that linger, like fields of frost that slow down her attackers, and radiant Holy bursts for clusters of enemies.

Her strength isn’t in brute force, but in pure, elegant battlefield control, slipping between attacks and using her magic to shape the space around her before the enemy even knows what’s happening. Narratively, she's central to one of Nightreign 's most unsettling arcs, with the unique "Bone-like Stone" item and the secret "Night of Love" ending being tied directly to her questline.

Bullet Witch

When Guns And Magic Violently Collide

Bullet Witch
Action
Systems
Released
July 27, 2006

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
M // Blood, Language, Violence
Developer(s)
Marvelous
Platform(s)
Xbox 360, Windows
Powered by

A glorious relic from the Xbox 360 era, Bullet Witch gave players Alicia, a powerful witch who is armed with both ancient, powerful spells and a fully customizable gun-rod. The post-apocalyptic setting is grim and gritty, filled with demons and twisted soldiers, but the game truly shines when it lets players combine its explosive, screen-filling magic with good old-fashioned, run-and-gun action.

Calling down a bolt of lightning from the heavens to fry an entire enemy squad, or summoning a massive tornado to rip a battlefield to shreds — it never stops being satisfying. The game has some serious rough edges, but that only adds to its wonderful, B-movie charm. It's a perfect pick for anyone who likes their witches loud, destructive, and unbothered by the concept of subtlety.

Wytchwood

Brewing Up Some Trouble, One Potion At a Time

wytchwood
10 /10
Released
December 9, 2021

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ due to Alcohol Reference, Crude Humor, Fantasy Violence, Mild Blood, Mild Language
Developer(s)
Alientrap
Platform(s)
PC, PS4, PS5, Switch
Powered by

And now for something completely different. Wytchwood is the most laid-back, cozy take on witchcraft gamers will ever find. Instead of frantic, flashy combat, the entire focus here is on crafting, puzzle-solving, and exploring a beautiful forest world that's full of strange creatures and twisted fables gone wrong.

Playing as a proper old witch, the game’s mischievous charm comes from the simple, satisfying loop of gathering weird ingredients, brewing them into potions, and then using those potions to curse the selfish, annoying villagers. The whole thing looks like it's been ripped straight from the pages of a children’s book, but the humor is surprisingly sharp and witty. Wytchwood is brilliant proof that being a witch doesn’t always mean hurling fireballs. Sometimes it’s about clever solutions and a good, healthy dose of snark.
